case_name: State of Andhra Pradesh v. Respondents

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 40 of 1965 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 4, 1964 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Criminal Revision Case No. 479 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 40 of 1965. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 4, 1964 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Criminal Revision Case No- 479 of 1964.

facts.text: The State of Andhra Pradesh appeals by special leave against the judgment of the High Court of Andhra Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Andhra Pradesh appeals by special leave against the judgment of the High Court of Andhra Pradesh in which, accepting a reference by the Sessions Judge, the conviction of the respondents under ss. 4 and 5 of the Hyderabad Gambling Act  2 of 1305F  ordered by the 5th City Magistrate at Secunderabad has been set aside.

facts.text: Andhra Pradesh High Court accepted a reference by the Sessions Judge and set aside the conviction of the respondents under sections 4 and 5 of the Hyderabad Gambling Act 2 of 1305F ordered by the 5th City Magistrate at Secunderabad.

anchor.surface_text: in which, accepting a reference by the Sessions Judge, the conviction of the respondents under ss. 4 and 5 of the Hyderabad Gambling Act  2 of 1305F  ordered by the 5th City Magistrate at Secunderabad has been set aside. The short question in this case is whether the premises of a Club known as the Crescent Recreation Club situated in Secunderabad were being used as a common gambling house and whether the several respondents who were present at the time of the raid by the police could be said to be gambling therein.

facts.text: Premises of Crescent Recreation Club situated in Secunderabad.

anchor.surface_text: The short question in this case is whether the premises of a Club known as the Crescent Recreation Club situated in Secunderabad were being used as a common gambling house and whether the several respondents who were present at the time of the raid by the police could be said to be gambling therein.

facts.text: On May 4, 1963, the police headed by Circle Inspector Krishnaswami raided the premises of the club.

anchor.surface_text: The facts of the case are as follows -- On May 4, 1963, the police headed by Circle Inspector Krishnaswami raided the premises of the club. They found respondents 1-5 playing a card game known as Rummy for stakes.

facts.text: Respondents 1-5 were found playing a card game known as Rummy for stakes at the time of the raid.

anchor.surface_text: They found respondents 1-5 playing a card game known as Rummy for stakes. At the time of the raid, there were some counters on the table as also money and of course the playing-cards with the players.

facts.text: At the time of the raid, there were some counters on the table as also money and playing-cards with the players.

anchor.surface_text: At the time of the raid, there were some counters on the table as also money and of course the playing-cards with the players. Respondent No. 6, the Treasurer of the Club, was also present and was holding the stake money which is popularly known as kitty.

facts.text: Respondent No. 6, the Treasurer of the Club, was present and holding the stake money known as kitty.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 6, the Treasurer of the Club, was also present and was holding the stake money which is popularly known as kitty. The 7th respondent is the Secretary of the Club and he has been joined as an accused, because he was in charge of the management of the club.

facts.text: The kitty held by the sixth respondent was Rs. 74.62nP and a further sum of Rs. 218/- was recovered from the table of the 6th respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The 7th respondent is the Secretary of the Club and he has been joined as an accused, because he was in charge of the management of the club. The kitty which the sixth respondent held was Rs. 74.62nP and a further sum of Rs. 218/- was recovered from the table of the 6th respondent.

facts.text: 66 counters were on the table and some more money was found with the persons who were indulging in the game.

anchor.surface_text: The kitty which the sixth respondent held was Rs. 74.62nP and a further sum of Rs. 218/- was recovered from the table of the 6th respondent. 66 counters were on the table and some more money was found with the persons who were indulging in the game.

facts.text: The 7th respondent is the Secretary of the Club and was in charge of the management of the club.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 6, the Treasurer of the Club, was also present and was holding the stake money which is popularly known as kitty. The 7th respondent is the Secretary of the Club and he has been joined as an accused, because he was in charge of the management of the club.

facts.text: Circle Inspector received credible information that the premises of the club were being used as a common gambling house and raided it.

anchor.surface_text: The evidence of the Circle Inspector is that he had received credible information that the premises of the club were being used as a common gambling house and he raided it and found evidence, because instruments of gambling were found and the persons present were actually gambling.

facts.text: The Magistrate convicted all the seven respondents and sentenced them to various fines, with imprisonment in default.

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate convicted all the seven respondents and sentenced them to various fines, with imprisonment in default. The respondents then filed an. application for revision before the Sessions Judge, Secunderabad who made a reference to the High Court under s. 438 of the Code of Criminal Procedure,

facts.text: Respondents filed application for revision before Sessions Judge, Secunderabad, who made a reference to High Court under s. 438 CrPC recommending quashing of conviction.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents then filed an. application for revision before the Sessions Judge, Secunderabad who made a reference to the High Court under s. 438 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, recommending the quashing of the conviction and the setting aside of the sentences.

facts.text: Learned single Judge in High Court accepted the recommendation and set aside the conviction.

anchor.surface_text: This recommendation was accepted by the learned single Judge in the High Court and the present appeal is brought against his judgment by special leave granted by this Court.

facts.text: On appearance of police, players stopped their play and arrests were promptly made.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case on the appearance of the police, it is admitted, the players stopped their play and the arrests were promptly made of all the persons present round the table who had cards, counters and the money with them.

facts.text: Sessions Judge opined that Rummy is a game of skill citing cases, and no profit made by club.

anchor.surface_text: In the order making the reference the learned Sessions Judge made two points He first referred to s. 14 of the Act which provides that nothing done under the Act shall apply to any game of mere skill wherever played and he was of opinion on the authority of two cases decided by the Madras High Court and one of the Andhra High Court that the, game of Rummy was a name of skill and therefore the Act did not apply to the case.

facts.text: High Court single Judge relied on no profit made by club, charging service charge.

anchor.surface_text: In accepting the reference, the learned single Judge in the High Court did not express any opinion upon the question whether the game of Rummy can be described as a game of skill. He relied upon the second part of the proposition which the Sessions Judge had suggested as the ground for acquitting the accused. namely, that the club was not making a profit but was only charging something as a service charge

facts.text: Club charged 5 points per game, Rs. 3/- extra for playing cards, Re. 1/- sitting fee per person, late fee if beyond time, and non-members also pay.

anchor.surface_text: He next points out that playing cards were supplied to the players by the club at an extra charge of Rs. 3/- and there was a sitting fee of Re. 1/- per person from those who joined the game. He points out further that if the game continued beyond a certain time in the night, a late fee was also levied. In addition, he says, that non-members were also required to pay

facts.text: Account books show fee of 50 paise per person playing in card room.

anchor.surface_text: In this connection, the account books of the club have been produced before us and they show that a fee of 50 paise is charged per person playing in the card room.

facts.text: No entry in account-books showing 5 points per game levy.

anchor.surface_text: Only the Sub-Inspector W. 6  deposes to it but there is nothing to show what his source of information was. At the time the game was going on, he was not present and when he arrived on the scene, the game had stopped. The account-books of the club do not show any such levy from the persons

facts.text: Court takes judicial notice that late fee is generally charged in clubs for use beyond scheduled time.

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, a late fee is generally charged from members who use the club premises beyond the scheduled time. This is necessary, because the servants of the club who attend on the members have to be paid extra remuneration by way of overtime and expenditure on light and other amenities has to be incurred beyond the club hours. Such a charge is usual in most of the clubs and we can take judicial notice of the fact.

facts.text: Game of Rummy requires skill in memorising fall of cards, holding and discarding.

anchor.surface_text: Rummy, on the other hand, requires certain amount of skill because the fall of the cards has to be memorised and the building up of Rummy requires considerable skill in holding and discarding cards. We cannot, therefore, say that the game of Rummy is a game of entire chance.

facts.text: Rummy is mainly and preponderantly a game of skill.

anchor.surface_text: It is mainly and preponderantly a game of skill. The chance in Rummy is of the same character as the chance in a deal at a game of bridge.

facts.text: High Court was right in accepting the reference.

anchor.surface_text: In this case, these elements are missing and therefore we think that the High Court was right in accepting the reference it did.

holdings.text: the points made by Mr. Ram Reddy do not prove this club to be a common gambling house
holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner's evidence of charges (5 points unproved, others reasonable service fees usual in clubs) insufficient to show profit/gain required by s.3 definition

holdings.text: The presumption under s. 7, even if it arises in this case, is successfully repelled by the evidence which has been led, even on the side of the prosecution
holdings.reasoning_summary: Prosecution evidence itself shows no profit/gain and game of skill rebuts presumption of common gambling house and persons gambling

holdings.text: a fee of 5 points per game was being charged... has not been proved
holdings.reasoning_summary: No account entry, witness absent during game, source unknown; insufficient proof

holdings.text: extra charge for playing cards unless it is extravagant would not show that the club was making a profit or gain so as to render the club into a common gambling house

anchor.surface_text: As regards the extra.charge for playing cards we may say that clubs usually make an extra charge for anything they Supply to their members because it is with the extra payments that the management

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clubs charge for supplies to cover amenities; analogous to fees for other games like billiards

holdings.text: a late fee is generally charged from members who use the club premises beyond the scheduled time... Such a charge is usual in most of the clubs and we can take judicial notice of the fact
holdings.reasoning_summary: Judicial notice of customary practice to cover overtime costs; not profit

holdings.text: a fee of 50 paise is charged per person playing in the card room. This to our opinion is not such a heavy charge in a Members Club as to be described as an attempt to make a profit or gain for the club
holdings.reasoning_summary: Account books confirm low sitting fee; reasonable, not profit-making

holdings.text: We are also not satisfied that the protection of s. 14 is not available in this case
holdings.reasoning_summary: Rummy requires skill (memorize cards, hold/discard); preponderant skill, chance element like bridge deal

holdings.text: the game of Rummy is a game of entire chance. It is mainly and preponderantly a game of skill
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished from pure chance games; skill in memory and strategy predominates
